d6707dc71db.title: This is the sort of thing that mostly resounds into an echo chamber.

paragraphs.text: This is the sort of thing that mostly resounds into an echo chamber. “Lynch” has been used in this context for an extremely long time — if it is a buzz word, it is a very tired one. Most Americans probably don’t know what a pillory is any more — but they do know lynching.

Not to mention missing women. If you’re interested, the TRC executive summary is available in PDF, audio, and YouTube (honestly I “read” it while doing my morning routine). However…

paragraphs.text: Didn’t that hack Tom Flanagan do the same thing as well?
paragraphs.name: 39a1

paragraphs.text: Enter Joseph Boyden here in Canada. The First Nations experience here in Canada is filled with struggle. It didn’t end in the 1870s; it barely ended in the 1980s. There are still reservations in Canada which don’t receive clean drinking water. There are still Natives alive today who experienced the horrors of the Residential School Scandal. Eugenics, aka forced sterilization, were committed on First Nations in Alberta until the ’70s. There are people alive who remember these experiences first-hand.
paragraphs.name: 871c

paragraphs.text: I’m totally fine about just about everything you say, except the patronizing “lynching looks nothing like” the picture I chose. Sure it does. Some of the time. Not all of the time, obviously. I know it covered a wide range, but hanging certainly did factor into it.
paragraphs.name: 73db

paragraphs.text: White folks, we don’t get lynched. We don’t have a clue what lynching is like, or what the spectre of its possibility would feel like in our lives, ever. We don’t have that history. (I’ve been reminded of history on this; yes, white folk have been, but it’s been awhile, and far less frequently than blacks.)
paragraphs.name: cf16

paragraphs.text: For Boyden to just casually insert himself into that cultural heritage and reap societal acclaim and reward for it, that’s something that First Nations people have a right to have a beef with.
paragraphs.name: 850e
